head.title: How Can Musicians Protect Their Art?

hedline.hl1: How Can Musicians Protect Their Art?

abstract.p: Christopher A Martin letter suggests that recording companies and publishers could produce virus-laden versions of copyrighted material for less-than-legitimate distribution on Internet (S)

block.p: Clay Shirky (''Freedom, One Song at a Time,'' Op-Ed, July 15) is correct in his assessment of the effects of Internet technology on recorded music, and for that matter copyrighted material of any form. Would it not be possible for artists and writers to protect their creations by using computer viruses?

Clay Shirky (''Freedom, One Song at a Time,'' Op-Ed, July 15) is correct in his assessment of the effects of Internet technology on recorded music, and for that matter copyrighted material of any form. Would it not be possible for artists and writers to protect their creations by using computer viruses?

Recording companies and publishers could produce virus-laden versions of their copyrighted material for less-than-legitimate distribution sources on the Internet. This would make promiscuous downloading from unofficial sites an inherently risky act. Indeed, this use of the formerly needless nuisance technology of viruses by copyright holders would be an aggressive measure, but it is arguably appropriate in the face of a great threat to their artistic and intellectual property.
CHRISTOPHER A. MARTIN New York, July 16, 2000
